{{Infobox person | name = Hannah Graham | image = File:Hannah Graham.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Hannah Elizabeth Graham | birth_date = February 25, 1996{{cite web|url=http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/timesdispatch.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/22/1222a26c-4447-11e4-83d1-0017a43b2370/54235b8b0ccc9.pdf.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 27, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141004074841/http://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/timesdispatch.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/22/1222a26c-4447-11e4-83d1-0017a43b2370/54235b8b0ccc9.pdf.pdf |archivedate=October 4, 2014 }} | birth_place = [[Royal Berkshire Hospital]]
[[Reading, Berkshire]], [[England]]
[[United Kingdom]]{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/for-hannah-grahams-family-nightmare-leaves-enduring-uncertainty-and-loss/2014/11/14/4849784a-6c2c-11e4-a31c-77759fc1eacc_story.html |title=For Hannah Graham's family, 'nightmare' leaves enduring uncertainty and loss |work=[[Washington Post]] |first=T. Rees |last=Shapiro |date=14 November 2014 |accessdate=15 November 2014}} | disappeared_date = {{nowrap| {{disappeared date|2014|09|13|1996|02|25}} }} | disappeared_place = [[Downtown Mall]]
[[Charlottesville, Virginia]], [[United States]] | disappeared_status = Remains recovered October 18, 2014 | death_date = {{circa}} {{death date and age|2014|09|13|1996|02|25}} | death_place = [[Albemarle County, Virginia]], United States | death_cause = Homicidal violence of undetermined etiology{{cite news |url=http://www.nbc29.com/story/27416684/update-police-release-cause-manner-of-death-in-graham-case |title=UPDATE: Police Release Cause, Manner of Death in Graham Case |work=[[WVIR]] |date=18 November 2014 |accessdate=18 November 2014}} | body_discovered = {{coord|37|55|26|N|78|36|55.5|W|type:event|display=inline}}
3193 Old Lynchburg Road{{cite news |first=Coy |last=Barefoot |title=EXCLUSIVE: Where Hannah Was Found |url=http://insidecville.com/blog/exclusive-where-hannah-was-found/ |work=Inside Cville |date=19 October 2014 |accessdate=21 October 2014}}
[[North Garden, Virginia|North Garden]], Virginia
October 18, 2014 | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | education = [[West Potomac High School]]
[[University of Virginia]] | height = {{height|ft=5|in=11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.missingkids.com/poster/NCMC/1237926/1 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=October 21, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141009025219/http://www.missingkids.com/poster/NCMC/1237926/1 |archivedate=October 9, 2014 }} | weight = {{convert|130|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} | parents = | relatives = }} '''Hannah Elizabeth Graham''' (February 25, 1996 – {{circa}} September 13, 2014) was an 18-year-old second-year [[British American]] student at the [[University of Virginia]] who went missing on September 13, 2014. She was last seen early in the morning that day, at the [[Downtown Mall]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]].{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/09/19/us/virginia-missing-student-hannah-graham/ | title=Major break: Police search car, apartment in case of missing Virginia student | work=CNN | date=19 September 2014 | accessdate=19 September 2014 | author=Carter, Chelsea}} Five weeks later, her remains were discovered on an abandoned property in nearby [[Albemarle County, Virginia|Albemarle County]]. Jesse Matthew pled guilty to murdering Graham and was given a lifetime prison sentence. He was also found guilty and sentenced to three additional lifetimes for other, previous crimes. ==Background== Graham's friends last heard from her via text message at about 1:20 am that day, after she told them she was on her way to a party, but was lost.{{cite web | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/09/19/missing-virginia-student/15890571/ | title=Police ID man who left bar with missing U.Va. student | work=USA Today | date=19 September 2014 | accessdate=19 September 2014 | author=Vasiliadis, Joanne}} She had attended another party before disappearing.{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/hannah-graham-what-happened-missing-virginia-student-n208556 | title=Hannah Graham: What Happened to the Missing Virginia Student? | work=NBC News | date=22 September 2014 | accessdate=22 September 2014 | author=Stelloh, Tim}} According to surveillance footage and witness testimony, among the last places she was seen was at Tempo Restaurant with Jesse Leeroy Matthew Jr., a 32-year-old man and [[person of interest]]. A witness also said that Matthew was seen in the restaurant holding an arm around Graham, and that she looked drunk. Because Graham was below the US [[legal drinking age]], Tempo Restaurant could face legal action if these sightings are confirmed.{{cite web | url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/bar-center-missing-uva-student-case-face-legal/story?id=25787415 | title=Bar at Center of Missing UVA Student Case May Face Legal Trouble | work=ABC News | date=27 September 2014 | accessdate=27 September 2014}} The last witness to see Hannah Graham alive says that Graham was with a man who "did not look friendly." As Graham was standing by a vehicle identified to be Matthew's orange 1998 [[Chrysler Sebring]], the witness heard her say, "I'm not getting in that car with you!"{{cite news|title=Statement of Facts Reveal New Details in Graham and Harrington Cases|url=http://www.nbc29.com/story/31371788/statement-of-facts-reveal-new-details-in-graham-and-harrington-cases|accessdate=3 March 2016|publisher=NBC29|date=March 2, 2016}} Over a decade earlier, Matthew was twice accused of sexual assault at two separate Virginia colleges he attended as a student; he left each school immediately after each allegation. The reported assaults occurred within an 11-month period of each other: from 2002 to 2003 as Jesse Leeroy "LJ" Matthew, Jr. moved from the evangelical Christian [[Liberty University]] in [[Lynchburg, VA|Lynchburg]] to the [[Christopher Newport University]] in [[Newport News]]. Police investigated each report, but in neither incident was a criminal case brought against him.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/court-hearing-for-suspect-in-disappearance-of-u-va-student-hannah-graham-moved/2014/10/01/e2b66508-4988-11e4-b72e-d60a9229cc10_story.html |title=U-Va. suspect Jesse L. Matthew Jr. twice accused of college sex assaults|work=The Washington Post|date= October 1, 2014}} ==Search== ===Volunteer search=== On September 20, a volunteer search for Graham took place throughout [[Charlottesville]]. Over 1,000 volunteers were reported to have been involved in the search.{{cite web | url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/article2180909.html | title=Hundreds search for missing UVa student | work=Miami Herald | date=20 September 2014 | accessdate=20 September 2014 | author=Suderman, Alan}} ===Search efforts=== On September 25, Charlottesville police chief Timothy Longo said he believed that Graham was either in Charlottesville or one of the surrounding nine counties, and asked property owners to search for her on their own land.{{cite web | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/police-ask-property-owners-to-help-search-for-hannah-graham/ | title=Police ask property owners to help search for Hannah Graham | work=CBS News | date=25 September 2014 | accessdate=25 September 2014 | author=Crimesider Staff}} The Department of Emergency Management organized two-person search teams in the search for Graham and estimated that as of September 26, those crews spent 44 hours in the field since the volunteer search.{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/09/26/with-suspect-in-custody-significant-challenges-remain-in-missing-uva-student/ | title=Challenges remain in case of missing UVA student | work=Fox News Channel | date=26 September 2014 | accessdate=26 September 2014 | agency=Associated Press}} ===Remains found=== On October 18, 2014, human remains were found at an abandoned property in [[Albemarle County, Virginia]], by searchers from the [[Chesterfield County Sheriff's Office]]. At a press conference later that day, Chief Longo stated that the remains had not been positively identified as Graham; however, authorities informed Graham's parents of the discovery. The remains were sent to the Chief Medical Examiner's office in [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] for identification.{{cite news |url=http://wtvr.com/2014/10/18/hannah-graham-update/ |title=Crew searching for missing UVa. student Hannah Graham finds human remains |work=[[WTVR-TV]] |date=18 October 2014 |accessdate=18 October 2014 |author=Scott Wise, Alix Bryan and Chelsea Rarrick}} On October 24, the remains were positively identified as Graham.{{cite news |url=http://www.nbc29.com/story/26886621/medical-examiner-confirms-hannah-grahams-remains-found-in-albemarle |title=Medical Examiner Confirms Hannah Graham's Remains Found in Albemarle |work=[[WVIR]] |date=24 October 2014 |accessdate=24 October 2014}} That same day, Graham's parents visited the property where she was found.{{cite news |url=http://www.nbc29.com/story/26883590/hannah-grahams-parents-visit-old-lynchburg-road-crime-scene |title=Hannah Graham's Parents Visit Old Lynchburg Road Crime Scene |work=[[WVIR]] |date=24 October 2014 |accessdate=24 October 2014 |first=Henry |last=Graff}} On November 18, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that a cause for Graham's death was determined but was withheld at the request of law enforcement.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/hannah-graham-cause-of-death-determined-officials-withholding-details/2014/11/18/2810156c-6f37-11e4-893f-86bd390a3340_story.html |title=Hannah Graham cause of death determined, officials withholding details |work=[[The Washington Post]] |first=T. Rees |last=Shapiro |date=18 November 2014 |accessdate=18 November 2014}} Later that day, the [[Albemarle County Police Department]] reversed course, releasing that Graham died of homicide by an "undetermined etiology".{{cite tweet |author= AlbemarleCoPolice |user= AlbemarleCoPD|number= 534827736691666944 |date= 18 November 2014 |title= "The cause of death is homicidal violence of undetermined etiology. The manner of death is homicide." |access-date= 19 November 2014 }} ==Suspect== On September 19, the local police identified a man they described as a "person of interest" whom they saw on surveillance cameras leaving a bar with Graham. The police have concluded that Graham may have gotten into a car with this man. They also searched the man's car and apartment, but declined to arrest or identify him at that time.{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/missing-uva-teen-spent-hours-before-disappearance-with-friends/2014/09/19/b425aab8-4001-11e4-b03f-de718edeb92f_story.html | title=Police scrutinize 'person of interest' seen with missing U-Va. student Hannah Graham | work=Washington Post | date=19 September 2014 | accessdate=19 September 2014 | author=Shapiro, T. Rees}} The police identified the "person of interest" as Jesse L. Matthew, Jr. the following day, in an effort to make contact with him for further questioning.{{cite web | url=http://www.timesdispatch.com/news/state-regional/police-confirm-person-of-interest-s-name-in-hannah-graham/article_33dd20b8-411c-11e4-994a-0017a43b2370.html | title=Police Confirm Person of Interest's Name in Hannah Graham Case | work=Richmond Times-Dispatch | date=20 September 2014 | accessdate=4 October 2014 | author=Brandon Shulleeta}} Police again searched Matthew's apartment on September 22;{{cite web | url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/hannah-graham-searchers-returns-jesse-matthews-apartment/story?id=25677711 | title=Hannah Graham Searchers Return to Jesse Matthew's Apartment | work=ABC News | date=22 September 2014 | accessdate=23 September 2014 | author=Keneally, Meghan}} during the search, they took items of clothing from his apartment, but would not elaborate on the importance of these items.{{cite news | url=http://www.chron.com/news/crime/article/Clothes-taken-in-search-for-missing-UVa-student-5774398.php | title=Clothes taken in search for missing UVa student | work=Houston Chronicle | date=23 September 2014 | accessdate=23 September 2014 | agency=Associated Press}} Police described the searches as a major break in the case and offered a $100,000 reward for information relating to Graham's disappearance.{{cite web | url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/missing-virginia-student-hannah-graham-car-man/story?id=25621541 | title=Missing Virginia Student Hannah Graham May Have Gotten Into Car With Man | work=ABC News | date=19 September 2014 | accessdate=20 September 2014 | author=Good Morning America}} ===Arrest=== On September 21, the police issued an arrest warrant for reckless driving by Jesse Matthew.{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/09/21/hundreds-volunteers-search-for-missing-university-virginia-student/ | title=Man seen with missing UVA student Hannah Graham faces driving charge | work=Fox News | date=21 September 2014 | accessdate=22 September 2014 | agency=Associated Press}} On September 23, Longo announced that Matthew had been charged with abduction with intent to defile.{{cite web | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/arrest-warrant-suspect-missing-university-of-virginia-student-hannah-graham/ | title=Arrest warrant for suspect in U.Va. missing case | work=CBS News | date=23 September 2014 | accessdate=23 September 2014 | author=Crimesider Staff}} On September 24, Longo, during a joint press conference with the FBI, announced that the suspect had been arrested in a sparsely populated part of [[Galveston County, Texas]] after being recognized by a woman on a beach.{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/hannah-graham-suspect-arrested-case-missing-uva-student-n210996 | title=Hannah Graham: Suspect Arrested in Case of Missing UVA Student | work=NBC News | date=24 September 2014 | accessdate=24 September 2014 | author=Gittens, Hasani}}{{cite web | url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Suspect-in-missing-UVA-student-s-abduction-5778791.php | title=Suspect in missing UVA student's abduction arrested in Galveston Co. | work=Houston Chronicle | date=25 September 2014 | accessdate=25 September 2014 | author=George, Cindy}} ===Connection to Morgan Harrington case=== {{see also|Murder of Morgan Dana Harrington}} The suspect has been forensically linked by the Virginia State Police to the [[murder of Morgan Dana Harrington]].{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/suspect-hannah-graham-disappearance-tied-2009-murder-police/story?id=25840656 |title=Suspect in Hannah Graham Disappearance Tied to 2009 Murder, Police Say|work=ABC News|date= September 29, 2014}} On September 29, 2014, it was reported that forensic evidence taken from the investigation into the murder of Morgan Dana Harrington matched evidence taken from Jesse Matthew. Sources close to the Graham investigation added that Harrington interacted with Matthew on the night she disappeared.{{cite web | url=http://wtkr.com/2014/09/29/breaking-forensic-evidence-links-hannah-graham-suspect-to-murdered-virginia-tech-student-morgan-harrington/ | title=BREAKING: Forensic evidence links Hannah Graham suspect to murdered Virginia Tech student Morgan Harrington | work=[[WTKR]] | date=29 September 2014 | accessdate=29 September 2014 | author=Mitchell, Becca}} Graham's remains were found about five miles from the location where Harrington's remains were discovered.{{cite news |url=http://wtvr.com/2014/10/18/legal-analyst-on-remains-discovery/ |title=What does discovery of remains mean for Hannah Graham suspect Jesse Matthew? |work=WTVR-TV |date=18 October 2014 |accessdate=19 October 2014}} Matthew attended [[Liberty University]], and later, [[Christopher Newport University]]; he was accused of sexual assault once at each of those universities. The first alleged incident occurred on October 17, 2002, and the second on September 7, 2003. On September 15, 2015, Matthew was formally charged with first degree murder and abduction with intent to defile in the murder of Morgan Harrington.{{cite news|url= http://www.wdbj7.com/news/local/jesse-matthew-charged-in-murder-of-morgan-harringto/35290040/|title= Jesse Matthew charged in murder of Morgan Harrington|work= WDBJ 7|date= September 15, 2015|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150916170939/http://www.wdbj7.com/news/local/jesse-matthew-charged-in-murder-of-morgan-harringto/35290040|archivedate= September 16, 2015|df= }} In a February 29, 2016 letter to news media, prosecutors said Matthew would plead guilty.{{cite news|author=T. Rees Shapiro |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/jesse-matthew-to-plead-in-graham-and-harrington-cases/2016/02/29/1b7cf44e-df1d-11e5-846c-10191d1fc4ec_story.html |title=Jesse Matthew to enter guilty pleas in Graham and Harrington cases |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2012-12-14 |accessdate=2016-05-19}} Matthew pled guilty and received four additional life terms.{{cite news|author=T. Rees Shapiro |author2=Justin Jouvenal |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/jesse-matthew-to-appear-in-court-for-plea-agreement-hearing/2016/03/01/f6b7093a-dfd8-11e5-846c-10191d1fc4ec_story.html?hpid=hp_local-news_matthew-1230pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory |title=Jesse Matthew pleads guilty in slayings of college students |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2012-12-14 |accessdate=2016-05-19}} He is currently at [[Red Onion State Prison]].https://vadoc.virginia.gov/offenders/locator/results.aspx ===Legal proceedings=== Matthew's first court appearance was scheduled for December 4, 2014.{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/court-hearing-for-suspect-in-disappearance-of-u-va-student-hannah-graham-moved/2014/10/01/e2b66508-4988-11e4-b72e-d60a9229cc10_story.html | title=U-Va. suspect Jesse L. Matthew Jr. twice accused of college sex assaults | work=Washington Post | date=1 October 2014 | accessdate=1 October 2014 | author=Flaherty, Mary Pat}} Matthew's attorney stated that he would not ask the court for bail for his client.{{cite web|url=http://www.wdbj7.com/news/local/jesse-matthews-attorney-wont-ask-for-bond-at-thursday-hearing/28352766|title=UPDATE: Jesse Matthew's reckless driving hearing continued to Dec. 1|website=Wdbj7.com|accessdate=18 October 2014}} On February 10, 2015, Albemarle County commonwealth's attorney Denise Lunsford announced that Matthew was being indicted for first-degree murder of Graham, in addition to the abduction charges.{{cite web |url=http://wtvr.com/2015/02/10/jesse-matthew-murder-charge/ |title=Jesse Matthew indicted on murder charge in death of UVa. student Hannah Graham |first1=Scott |last1=Wise |first2=Jake |last2=Burns |first3=Laura |last3=French |publisher=[[WTVR-TV|WTVR]] |date=February 10, 2015 |accessdate=February 10, 2015 }} On May 5, 2015, prosecutors announced that Matthew would be charged with [[capital murder]]. The increased charge of capital murder meant that Matthew could have faced the death penalty if convicted.{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/05/us/jesse-matthew-hannah-graham-capital-murder/ | title=Hannah Graham case: Jesse Matthew charged with capital murder | work=CNN | date=5 May 2015 | accessdate=5 May 2015 | author=Shoichet, Catherine E.}} The trial date was set for July 5, 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc29.com/story/29406490/jesse-matthew-capital-murder-trial-date-set |title=Jesse Matthew Capital Murder Trial Date Set - NBC29 WVIR Charlottesville, VA News, Sports and Weather |website=Nbc29.com |date= |accessdate=2016-05-19}} On March 2, 2016, Matthew pled guilty.{{cite news|last1=Catherine E. Shoichet|title=Jesse Matthew Jr. pleads guilty to killing Hannah Graham, Morgan Harrington|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2016/03/02/us/jesse-matthew-plea-hearing/index.html|accessdate=20 May 2018|work=CNN|date=3 March 2016}} Later, Matthew received four additional life terms. ===Fairfax case=== On October 20, 2014, Matthew was indicted on charges of attempted murder, object sexual penetration, and abduction with intent to defile from an incident that occurred in September 2005 in [[Fairfax, Virginia]].{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/20/us/hannah-graham-disappearance/index.html | title=Hannah Graham suspect indicted in 2005 assault | work=CNN | date=20 October 2014 | accessdate=21 October 2014 | author=Ahmed, Saeed}}{{citation |title=Indictment for Attempted Capital Murder, Abduction and Sexual Penetration with an Object |url=http://ftpcontent.worldnow.com/wvir/documents/MatthewFairfaxIndictment.pdf |author=Circuit Court of Fairfax County |date=20 October 2014 |accessdate=21 October 2014}} On November 14, 2014, Matthew pleaded not guilty to the charges, and a trial was set to begin on March 9, 2015.{{cite news |url=http://wtop.com/149/3742278/Suspect-in-Va-college-student-kidnapping-in-court |title=Suspect in student kidnapping pleads not guilty |work=[[WTOP-FM]] |date=14 November 2014 |accessdate=14 November 2014}} On February 6, 2015, the Fairfax trial was postponed, with a new trial to be set on February 13.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/jesse-matthew-rape-trial-postponed/2015/02/06/a6f194f6-ad89-11e4-9c91-e9d2f9fde644_story.html?wprss=rss_crime |title=Jesse Matthew rape trial postponed |first=Justin |last=Jouvenal |publisher=Washington Post |date=February 6, 2015 |accessdate=February 10, 2015 }} On February 18, Matthew appeared in court, where Albemarle County Circuit Judge [[Cheryl Higgins]] scheduled his jury trial to begin on June 29.{{cite web | url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/us/article/June-trial-set-for-man-charged-in-Virginia-6087522.php | title=June trial set for man charged in Virginia student slaying | work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] | date=18 February 2015 | accessdate=18 February 2015 | author=O'Dell, Larry}} However, the trial began on June 8,{{cite news|last1=Fox|first1=Peggy|title=Victim describes brutal attack in Jesse Matthew trial|url=http://www.wusa9.com/story/news/2015/06/08/jesse-matthew-fairfax-trial-begins/28674783/|accessdate=11 June 2015|publisher=WUSA9}} and on June 10, Matthew abruptly entered an [[Alford plea]], and was convicted on all charges.{{cite news|last1=Shapiro|first1=T. Rees|title=Jesse Matthew convicted in 2005 sex assault case in Fairfax|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/expert-says-dna-found-under-victims-fingernail-a-clear-match-to-jesse-matthew/2015/06/10/34d22dce-0f7a-11e5-9726-49d6fa26a8c6_story.html|accessdate=11 June 2015|publisher=Washington Post}} On October 2, 2015, Matthew was sentenced to three life terms in the Fairfax case.{{cite news|title=Matthew Sentenced in 2005 sex assault case in Fairfax|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/jesse-matthew-to-be-sentenced-in-brutal-attack-on-woman-in-fairfax/2015/10/01/39bd9114-685f-11e5-8325-a42b5a459b1e_story.html|publisher=Washington Post}} ==Memorial== After Graham's remains were discovered and identified, students at the [[University of Virginia]] erected a memorial on campus in her honor.{{cite web | url=http://washington.cbslocal.com/2014/10/28/memorial-erected-at-uva-in-honor-of-hannah-graham/ | title=Memorial Erected at UVa in Honor of Hannah Graham | work=CBS Washington | date=28 October 2014 | accessdate=29 October 2014}} The [[World Bank]] also holds an annual award for innovations to reduce [[gender based violence]] held in memory of Hannah Graham.{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2018/04/17/innovative-researchers-fighting-gender-based-violence-win-more-than-1-million-dollars|title=Innovative Researchers Fighting Gender-Based Violence Win More Than $1 Million|work=World Bank|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Graham, Hannah}} [[Category:2014 murders in the United {{about|[[Tiberius]]' younger brother|his paternal grandfather with the name Drusus Claudius Nero|Drusus Claudius Nero I|his nephew with Nero Claudius Drusus as his birthname|Drusus Julius Caesar}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Nero Claudius Drusus | image = Drusus l'ancien Rome augGP2014.jpg | caption = Bust of Nero Claudius Drusus, in the [[Capitoline Museums]], [[Rome]] | full name = Decimus Claudius Drusus{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=3}}
(at birth);
Nero Claudius Drusus
(afterwards);
Nero Claudius Drusus Germanicus
(posthumously) | spouse = [[Antonia Minor]] | issue = [[Germanicus]]
[[Livilla]]
[[Claudius]], Roman Emperor | father = [[Tiberius Claudius Nero (praetor 42 BC)|Tiberius Claudius Nero]] | mother= [[Livia|Livia Drusilla]] | birth_date = January 14, 38 BC | birth_place = [[Roman Italy|Italia]] | death_date = Summer of 9 BC (aged 29) | death_place = [[Germania]] | place of burial = [[Mausoleum of Augustus]] }} '''Nero Claudius Drusus Germanicus''' (January 14, 38 BC – summer of 9 BCSuetonius, [[The Twelve Caesars]], Claudius, 1), born '''Decimus Claudius Drusus''',{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=3}} also called '''Drusus Claudius Nero''',[http://www.roman-emperors.org/tiberius.htm De Imperatoribus Romanis - An Online Encyclopedia of Roman Emperors, Tiberius (A.D. 14-37), written by Garrett G. Fagan of Pennsylvania State University] '''Drusus''', '''Drusus I''', '''Nero Drusus''', or '''Drusus the Elder''' was a [[Roman Empire|Roman]] politician and military commander. He was a [[Patrician (ancient Rome)|patrician]] [[Claudia (gens)|Claudian]] on his legal father's side but his maternal grandmother was from a [[plebeian]] family. He was the son of [[Livia|Livia Drusilla]] and the legal stepson of her second husband, the Emperor [[Augustus]]. He was also brother of the Emperor [[Tiberius]], father to both the Emperor [[Claudius]] and general [[Germanicus]], paternal grandfather of the Emperor [[Caligula]], and maternal great-grandfather of the Emperor [[Nero]]. He launched the first major Roman campaigns across the [[Rhine]] and began the conquest of [[Germania]], becoming the first Roman general to reach the [[Weser]] and [[Elbe]] rivers. In 12 BC, Drusus led a successful [[Early Imperial campaigns in Germania|campaign]] into Germania, subjugating the [[Sicambri]]. Later that year he led a naval expedition against Germanic tribes along the [[North Sea]] coast, conquering the [[Batavi (Germanic tribe)|Batavi]] and the [[Frisii]], and defeating the [[Chauci]] near the mouth of the Weser. In 11 BC, he conquered the [[Usipetes]] and the [[Marsi (Germanic)|Marsi]], extending Roman control to the Upper Weser. In 10 BC, he launched a campaign against the [[Chatti]] and the resurgent Sicambri, subjugating both. The following year, while serving as [[Roman consul|consul]], he conquered the [[Mattiaci]] and defeated the [[Marcomanni]] and the [[Cherusci]], the latter near the Elbe. However, Drusus died later that year, depriving Rome of one of its best generals. ==Childhood== Drusus was the youngest son of [[Livia|Livia Drusilla]] from her marriage to [[Tiberius Claudius Nero (praetor 42 BC)|Tiberius Claudius Nero]], who was legally declared his father before the couple divorced. Drusus was born between mid-March and mid-April 38 BC, three months after Livia married [[Augustus]] on 17 January.Donna W. Hurley, ''Suetonius: Divus Claudius'' (Cambridge University Press, 2001), [https://books.google.com/books?id=9yVR5Fac278C&pg=PA106 p. 106] Gerhard Radke has proposed the date of March 28 as his most likely [[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#dies natalis|birthday]],At ''Divus Claudius'' [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Suetonius/12Caesars/Claudius*.html#11.3 11.3], Suetonius says that Claudius as emperor commemorated the birthday ''([[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#dies natalis|dies natalis]])'' of his father Drusus on the same date as that of [[Mark Antony]], his maternal grandfather, whose birthday on January 14, ca. 83 BC, had been decreed as a "defective" day ''([[dies vitiosus]])'' by Augustus ([[Cassius Dio]] [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/51*.html#19.3 51.9.3]). However, since Drusus's birth is also recorded as occurring within the third month after Livia's marriage to Augustus on January 17, Radke proposes that Claudius used the astronomical discrepancies between the [[Roman calendar|pre-Julian calendar]] under which Antony was born and the [[Julian calendar]] in effect at the time of Drusus' birth, to show that had the two been born under the same calendar, they would have shared a birthday. Gilbert Radke (1978), "Der Geburtstag des älteren Drusus," ''Wurzburger Jahrbucher fur die Altertumswissenschaft'' 4 (1978), pp. 211–213. Reviewing these theories, Anthony A. Barrett still considers January 14 the most probable birthdate, explaining the apparent three-month discrepancy as referring to Livia's betrothal, not her marriage {{harv|Barrett|2002|pages=313–314}}. while Lindsay Powell interprets Ovid's ''Fasti'' as indicating a date of 13 January.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=3}} Rumors arose that Augustus was the child's real father, although this has never been authoritatively proven. Claudius, however, encouraged the rumor during his reign as emperor to create an impression of more direct lineage from Augustus. According to [[Suetonius]], Drusus was originally given ''Decimus'' as his [[praenomen]], the first of a Roman male's conventional three names in [[Roman naming convention|Roman naming practice]] at the time. ''Nero'' was a traditional [[cognomen]] (third name) of the [[Claudia (gens)|Claudii]], whereas ''Drusus'' was given to a branch of the ''[[Livia (gens)|gens Livia]]''. Using a cognomen such as ''Nero'' as a first name was unusual, as was the prominence given to his maternal lineage in adopting ''Drusus'' as his cognomen. Drusus was raised in Claudius Nero's house with his brother, the future emperor [[Tiberius]], until his legal father's death. The two brothers developed a famously close relationship that would last the rest of their lives. Tiberius named his eldest son after his brother, and Drusus did likewise, although eldest sons were usually named after their father or grandfather. == Marriage == [[File:Hera Ludovisi Altemps Inv8631.jpg|left|upright=0.8|thumb|The [[Juno Ludovisi]], a 1st-century CE depiction of Drusus' wife Antonia Minor as [[Juno (deity)|Juno]]]] Drusus married [[Antonia Minor]], the daughter of [[Mark Antony]] and Augustus' sister, [[Octavia Minor]], and gained a reputation of being completely faithful to her.[[Valerius Maximus]], ''[[Factorum ac dictorum memorabilium libri IX]]'' IV.3.3 [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/L/Roman/Texts/Valerius_Maximus/4*.html (Latin text)]. Cited in {{harvp|Powell|2011|page=91}}. Their children were [[Germanicus]], [[Claudius]], a daughter named [[Livilla (sister of Claudius)|Livilla ('little Livia')]], and at least two others who did not survive infancy. After Drusus' death, Antonia never remarried, though she outlived him by nearly five decades. Three emperors were direct descendants of Drusus: his son [[Claudius]], his grandson [[Caligula]], and his great-grandson [[Nero]]. ==Career== Augustus bestowed many honors on his stepsons. In 19 BC, Drusus was granted the ability to hold all public offices five years before the minimum age. When Tiberius left Italy during his term as praetor in 16 BC, Drusus legislated in his place. He became quaestor the following year, fighting against [[Raetia]]n bandits in the [[Alps]]. Drusus repelled them, gaining honors, but was unable to smash their forces, and required reinforcement from Tiberius. The brothers easily defeated the local Alpine tribes. Drusus arrived in Gaul in late 15 BCE to serve as ''legatus Augusti pro praetore'' (governor on Augustus' behalf with the authority of a praetor) of the three Gaulish provinces.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=48-49}} His contribution to the ongoing building and urban development in Gaul can be seen in the establishment of the ''pes Drusianus'', or ‘Drusian [[Foot (unit)|foot]]’, of about {{convert|33.3|cm|in|abbr=on}}, which was in use in [[Amiens#Antiquity|Samarobriva]] (modern [[Amiens]]) and among the [[Tungri]].{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=53-54}} From 14 to 13 BCE, Augustus himself was also active in Gaul, whether in Lugdunum (modern Lyon) or along the Rhine frontier.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=48, 61, 70}} As governor of Gaul, Drusus made his headquarters at Lugdunum, where he decided to establish the ''concilium Galliarum'' or ‘council of the Gaulish provinces’ sometime between 14 and 12 BCE.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=56}} This council would elect from its members a priest to celebrate games and venerate [[dea Roma|Rome]] and [[Augustus]] as deities{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=56-57}} every 1 August at the altar of the three Gauls that Drusus established at [[La Croix-Rousse|Condate]] in 10 BCE.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=97-99}} Drusus' son Tiberius—the future emperor [[Claudius]]—was born in Lugdunum on the same day that this altar was inaugurated.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=99}} ===Germanic campaigns=== {{Further|Early Imperial campaigns in Germania}} [[File:Druso in Germania per Wikipedia.JPG|thumb|right|upright=1.4|Map of Drusus' campaigns against the [[Germanic peoples|Germanic tribes]], 12-9 BC]] Starting in 14 BCE, Drusus built a string of military bases along the Rhine—fifty according to [[Florus]]—and established an alliance with the [[Batavi (Germanic tribe)|Batavi]] in preparation for military action in Germania Libera.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=62-64}} He is likely to have had seven legions under his command.These were, according to {{harvp|Powell|2011|page=61}}, [[Legio I Germanica|Legiones I Germanica]], [[Legio V Alaudae|V Alaudae]], [[Legio XIII Gemina|XIII Gemina]], [[Legio XIV Gemina|XIV Gemina]], [[Legio XVI Gallica|XVI Gallica]], [[Legio XVII|XVII]], [[Legio XVIII|XVIII]], and [[Legio XIX|XIX]] (the last three being the legions that would [[Battle of the Teutoburg Forest|later be destroyed]] while under the command of [[Publius Quinctilius Varus|Varus]]). In spring of 12 BCE, he [[Early Imperial campaigns in Germania|embarked]] an expeditionary force, perhaps consisting of the [[Legio I Germanica|Legiones I Germanica]] and [[Legio V Alaudae|V Alaudae]], by ship from the vicinity of modern [[Nijmegen]], making use of one or more canals he had built for the purpose.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=64-65, 70}} Drusus sailed to the mouth of the [[Ems (river)|Ems]] and penetrated into the territory of the [[Chauci]] in present-day [[Lower Saxony]].{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=74, 77}} The Chauci concluded a treaty acknowledging Roman supremacy, and would remain allies of Rome for years to come.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=78}} As they continued to ascend the Ems, the Romans were attacked by the [[Bructeri]] in boats.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=78-79}} Drusus' forces defeated the Bructeri, but, as it was now late in the campaign season, turned back for their winter quarters in Gaul, taking advantage of their new alliance with the [[Frisii]] to navigate through the difficult conditions on the [[North Sea]].{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=79}} As a reward for the successes of his campaign in 12 BCE, Drusus was made ''[[praetor#Praetor urbanus|praetor urbanus]]'' for 11 BCE when he returned to Rome for the winter.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=79}} News of Drusus' achievements—navigating the North Sea, carrying the Roman eagles into new territory, and fixing new peoples into treaty relations with Rome—caused considerable excitement in Rome and were commemorated on coins.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=79}} Drusus did not have it in him to stay in Rome. In the spring of his term as ''praetor urbanus'', he set out for the German border once more. This time, he assembled a force consisting of all or part of five legions in addition to auxiliaries and, setting out from [[Xanten|Vetera]] on the Rhine, ascended the [[Lippe (river)|River Lippe]]. Here he encountered the [[Tencteri]] and [[Usipetes]], whom he defeated in two separate engagements.{{harvp|Powell|2011|page=81}}. The legions in question this time were the I Germanica, the V Alaudae, the XVII, the XVIII, and the XIX. He reached the [[Werra|Werra Valley]] before deciding to turn back for the season, as winter was coming on, supplies were dwindling, and the omens were unfavorable.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=83-84}} While his forces were making their way back through the territory of the [[Cherusci]], the latter tribe laid an ambush for them at Arbalo.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=89}} The Cherusci failed to capitalize on their initial advantage, whereupon the Romans broke through their lines, defeated the Germanic attackers, and acclaimed Drusus as ''imperator''.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=89}} To show his continued mastery of the ground, Drusus garrisoned a number of positions within Germania during the winter of 11–10 BCE, including one somewhere in [[Hesse]]{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=91}} and one in Cheruscan territory, probably either [[:de:Römerlager Haltern|the camp]] at [[Haltern am See|Haltern]] or [[:de:Römerlager Oberaden|that at]] [[Bergkamen|Bergkamen-Oberaden]],{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=90}} both in present-day [[North Rhine-Westphalia|North Rhine–Westphalia]]. He rejoined his wife Antonia and two children for a time in Lugdunum before the family returned to Rome, where Drusus reported to Augustus.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=91}} Drusus was given the honor of an [[ovation]], and for the second time, Augustus closed the doors of the [[Temple of Janus (Roman Forum)|Temple of Janus]], signifying that the whole Roman world was then at peace.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=92}} Drusus was granted the office of proconsul for the following year. In 10 BC, the [[Chatti]] joined with the [[Sicambri]] and attacked Drusus' camp, but they were driven back. Drusus pursued them, proceeding from the sites of present-day Mainz and [[:de:Römerlager Rödgen|Rödgen]], where he set up a base of supply, to [[Hedemünden]], where a strong new camp was established.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=xxvii, 93}} Around this time, the canny [[Marcomanni]]c king [[Maroboduus]] responded to the Roman incursion by relocating his people ''en masse'' to [[Bohemia]].{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=94}} In summer of 10 BCE, Drusus left the field in order to return to [[Lugdunum]], where he inaugurated the sanctuary of the Three Gaulish provinces at Condate on 1 August.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=97}} Augustus and Tiberius were in Lugdunum for this occasion (when Drusus' youngest son Claudius was born), and afterwards Drusus accompanied them back to Rome.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=99}} Drusus easily won election as [[Roman consul|consul]] for the year 9 BCE.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=100}} Once more he left the city before assuming office. His consulship conferred the chance for Drusus to attain Rome's highest and rarest military honor, the ''[[spolia opima]]'', or spoils of an enemy chieftain slain personally by an opposing Roman general who was fighting (as consuls did) under his own auspices.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=95}} He quickly returned to the field, stopping to confer with his staff at Lugdunum and to dedicate a temple to Caesar Augustus at [[Langres|Andemantunnum]], before rejoining his command at Mainz, from which the year's expedition departed in early spring.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=102}} Drusus led the army via Rödgen through the territories of the [[Marsi]] and [[Cherusci]] until he even crossed the river [[Elbe]].{{sfnp|Powell|2011|pages=102-104}} Here he is said to have seen an apparition of a Germanic woman who warned him against proceeding farther and that his death was near. Drusus turned back,{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=104}} erecting a trophy to commemorate his reaching the Elbe, perhaps on the site of Dresden or Magdeburg.{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=105}} Drusus had sought out multiple Germanic (at least three) chieftains during his campaigns in Germany (12 BCE–9 BCE), engaging them in "dazzling displays of single combat".{{sfnp|Powell|2011|page=94}} The sources are ambiguous, but imply that at some point he did take the ''spolia opima'' from a Germanic king, thus becoming the fourth and final Roman to gain this honor.{{harvp|Powell|2011|page=96}} and note 155 on p. 199, citing Suetonius ''Claudius'' I.4. ==Death and legacy== {{multiple image |total_width=375 |align=left |image1 = Drususstein Rekonstruktion Lehne.jpg |width1 = 706 |height1 = 1000 |image2 = The Cenotaph of Drusus (Drususstein), an empty tomb raised by Roman troops in 9 AD in honour of the deceased general Drusus, Mogontiacum (Mainz) (9739245693).jpg |width2 = 3264 |height2 = 4928 |footer=The [[Drususstein]], the funerary monument in Mogontiacum ([[Mainz]]) erected by legionaries in Drusus' honor. Left, a reconstruction of its original appearance; right, its current appearance.{{cite book | last = Kersting | first = Hans | authorlink = Hans Kersting | title = MAINZ - tours on foot | year = 2003 | publisher = Bayerische Verlagsanstalt | isbn = 3-89889-078-3 | volume = 4 | language = German }} }} Drusus was returning from his advance to the Elbe when he [[List of horse accidents|fell from his horse]],Barbara Levick, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Ev4CkGHgfMUC&pg=PA11&lpg=PA11&dq=Nero+Claudius+Drusus+death&source=bl&ots=Z6g7owKgkG&sig=7oYA_UDMvvhVPA9Ar7UtGXtTk-g&hl=en&sa=X&ei=POOAUN36FKSyiQeNoYC4Bw&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Nero%20Claudius%20Drusus%20death&f=false Claudius]'' (Yale University Press, Sep. 10, 1993), p. 11. lingering on for a month after the accident, by which point Tiberius had joined him. Shortly before his death he wrote a letter to Tiberius complaining about the style in which Augustus ruled. [[The Twelve Caesars|Suetonius]] reports that he had refused to return to Rome just before his death. Drusus' body was brought back to the city, and his ashes were deposited in the [[Mausoleum of Augustus]]. He remained extremely popular with the [[legionary|legionaries]], who erected a monument (the [[Drususstein]]) in ''Mogontiacum'' (modern [[Mainz]]) on his behalf. Remnants of this are still standing. His family was granted the hereditary honorific title "Germanicus", which was given to his eldest son before passing to his youngest. Augustus later wrote a biography of him which does not survive. By Augustus' decree, festivals were held in Mogontiacum at Drusus' death day and probably also on his birthday.Suetonius, ''Claudius'' I.1.3 Drusus' mother [[Livia]], much affected by the death of her second son, took the advice of the philosopher [[Arius Didymus|Areus]] to put up many statues and images of Drusus and speak often about him.{{sfnp|Barrett|2002|page=44}} The surviving Latin work ''[[Ovid#Consolatio ad Liviam .28.22Consolation to Livia.22.29|Consolatio ad Liviam]]'' is framed as an [[Ovid]]ian [[consolatio|message of consolation]] to Livia on this occasion, though it is generally considered a literary exercise "composed between the death of Livia [29 CE] and that of Tiberius [37 CE]".{{cite journal|title=Review of ''Consolatio ad Liviam'' by Arnold Witlox |author=Arnold M. Duff |journal=The Classical Review |volume=49 |number=4 |date=1935 |pages=155–156 |jstor=699709 |doi=10.1017/s0009840x00068323}} Augustus noted the successes of Drusus' campaigns—for which, as Drusus' superior, he took credit—in his ''[[Res Gestae Divi Augusti]]'', written in 14 CE: {{Quote|text=I restored peace to the provinces of Gaul and Spain, likewise Germany, which includes the ocean from Cadiz to the mouth of the river Elbe. [...] I sailed my ships on the ocean from the mouth of the Rhine to the east region up to the borders of the Cimbri, where no Roman had gone before that time by land or sea, and the Cimbri and the Charydes and the Semnones and the other Germans of the same territory sought by envoys the friendship of me and of the Roman people. |author=Augustus |source=''Res Gestae Divi Augusti''[[Augustus]], ''[[Res Gestae Divi Augusti]]'' 26. [http://classics.mit.edu/Augustus/deeds.html Translated] by Thomas Bushnell (2011) and placed by his permission [https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Deeds_of_the_Divine_Augustus on Wikisource]. Passage also quoted in {{harvp|Powell|2011|page=80}}.}} Upon [[Claudius]]' accession to the principate in 41 CE, his late father Drusus received new public honors, including annual games in the Circus Maximus on January 14 for Drusus' birthday, coin issues commemorating Drusus' victories in Germania, and the restoration of a monument near the [[Ara Pacis Augustae]] that featured a statue of Drusus.{{sfnp|Osgood|2011|pages=60-61}} Claudius also completed a road from Italy into [[Raetia]] that followed the route Drusus had taken and whose road-markers commemorated Drusus' achievements in the Alpine war.{{sfnp|Osgood|2011|page=188}} Such Claudian commemorations of Drusus' memory are thought to have become less prominent once Claudius had his own [[Roman conquest of Britain|British triumph]] to celebrate.{{sfnp|Osgood|2011|page=93}} ==Family tree== {{chart top|width=100%}} {{chart/start|align=center|style=font-size:90%; line-height: 120%; margin:1em;|summary=Family tree of Nero Claudius Drusus}} {{chart| | GRP1 |y| GRM1 | | GRP2 |y| GRM2 | | GRP1 = [[Drusus Claudius Nero I]] | GRM1 = Claudia | GRP2 = [[Marcus Livius Drusus Claudianus]] | GRM2 = [[Aufidia]]}} {{chart| | | | |!| | | | | | | |!| | | | }} {{chart| | | | Father |~|~|y|~|~| Mother | | | | Father = [[Tiberius Claudius Nero (praetor 42 BC)|Tiberius Claudius Nero]] | Mother = [[Livia]] }} {{chart| | | |,|-|-|-|-|(| | | | | | | | }} {{chart| | |Brother| | | NCD |y| Spouse | | | | | Brother = [[Tiberius]] | NCD = Nero Claudius Drusus | Spouse = [[Antonia Minor]] }} {{chart| | | | | | |,|-|-|-|+|-|-|-|.| | | }} {{chart| | | | | |Issue1| |Issue2| |Issue3| | | | Issue1 = [[Germanicus]] | Issue2 = [[Livilla]] | Issue3 = [[Claudius]] }} {{chart/end}} {{chart bottom}} ==In popular culture== He is a minor character in [[Robert Graves]]' historical novel ''[[I, Claudius]]'', as well as the [[I, Claudius (TV series)|BBC's adaptation]] of the same title. The Permian–Triassic extinction event is the most significant event for marine genera, with just over 50% (according to this source) perishing.
